docs.lead_paragraph: Unable to speak, Rob O'Neill moans in pain as his stomach and intestines struggle to digest food. It is a sound his parents have heard since July, when the only therapy that had helped him -- the heartburn drug Propulsid -- was pulled from pharmacy shelves. Propulsid's maker promised a special program to keep shipping the pill to certain people with no other relief, but doctors say many patients like Mr. O'Neill, a 22-year-old resident of Lexington, Ky., who cannot process food because of severe cerebral palsy, are still waiting.

headline.main: Ill Patients Fight to Keep Receiving Banned Drug

docs.abstract: Heartburn remedy Propulsid was banned from general use in July after Food and Drug Administration linked it to 80 deaths; for some patients with more serious disorders than simple heartburn, Propulsid was only treatment that pushed food through their partly paralyzed digestive tracts; FDA and drug's maker Janssen Pharmaceutica have created 'compassionate-use' system in which certain very ill patients can keep taking Propulsid in carefully monitored program, but hundreds of patients are frustrated at not being able to get on list (M)
docs.snippet: Unable to speak, Rob O'Neill moans in pain as his stomach and intestines struggle to digest food. It is a sound his parents have heard since July, when the only therapy that had helped him -- the heartburn drug Propulsid -- was pulled from pharmacy...

docs.lead_paragraph: Common house mice may be a major contributor to asthma among inner-city children, according to a federally financed study. Asthma affects about 15 million Americans, including 5 million children. An estimated 7 percent of children nationally have the disease, though researchers say it is twice as common in inner cities.

headline.main: House Mice May Contribute to Asthma Attacks

docs.snippet: Common house mice may be a major contributor to asthma among inner-city children, according to a federally financed study.    Asthma affects about 15 million Americans, including 5 million children. An estimated 7 percent of children nationally have...

docs.lead_paragraph: Adding new evidence that stress can be a wide-ranging threat to human health, researchers have found that elderly people under emotional pressure when they receive pneumonia vaccinations seem to reap less benefit from the shots. The findings come from a team of Ohio State University researchers who specialize in how stress affects the body's immune system. In the past, they have looked at how negative emotions appear to weaken other vaccinations -- among them rubella, hepatitis-B and flu -- and overall immunological strength.
docs.abstract: Ohio State University researchers find that elderly people who are under stress when they receive pneumonia vaccinations may receive less benefit from shots; study led by Dr Ron Glaser and Dr Janice Kiecolt-Glaser is published in journal Psychosomatic Medicine (S)
docs.snippet: Adding new evidence that stress can be a wide-ranging threat to human health, researchers have found that elderly people under emotional pressure when they receive pneumonia vaccinations seem to reap less benefit from the shots.    The findings come...

docs.lead_paragraph: Living in cities may be a health hazard. At least if you're a man under 65. The reasons are uncertain, but a study in the December issue of The American Journal of Public Health found that men who lived in urban areas were 62 percent more likely to die during the study period than men who lived in suburbs, small towns or rural areas.

headline.main: For Men, a Sadder Tale of the City

docs.abstract: Study reported in American Journal of Public Health finds significantly higher mortality rate from disease among men under age 65 who live in urban areas than among men who live in other settings; research was led by Dr James S House of University of Michigan; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Living in cities may be a health hazard. At least if you're a man under 65.    The reasons are uncertain, but a study in the December issue of The American Journal of Public Health found that men who lived in urban areas were 62 percent more likely...

docs.lead_paragraph: On the seacoast of New England, where men are men and health concerns are often left to the women, one researcher is trying to cure what he sees as an epidemic in men's health. Namely, that men ignore their aches and pains, mental and physical, until it is too late. For a study he began in 1998, Chuck Rhoades interviewed 73 men in New Hampshire and Maine about their attitudes toward health care. Their stories did not surprise him. ''I get an annual physical exam,'' one of the men told him, ''every 16 years.''

headline.main: Experiment Aims to Get Real Men to Go to the Doctor

docs.abstract: Project begun by Chuck Rhoades and sponsored by New Hampshire Charitable Foundation addresses widespread reluctance among men to visit doctors; project brings groups of men together to talk informally about health issues in effort to encourage lifestyle changes and willingness to seek treatment (M)
docs.snippet: On the seacoast of New England, where men are men and health concerns are often left to the women, one researcher is trying to cure what he sees as an epidemic in men's health. Namely, that men ignore their aches and pains, mental and physical, until...

docs.lead_paragraph: It is interesting that the Nova series on PBS chose the most food-focused month of the year to air a very candid program about eating disorders, its victims, its probable causes and the newest treatments for what psychiatrists rank among the most intractable mental problems and, for anorexia at least, the deadliest. While most of us will simply eat to excess from Thanksgiving to the New Year and then worry about shedding the holiday gains, those with eating disorders will either shun holiday fare (and most other food) entirely or gorge on it and then purge to avoid putting the extra calories on their waists and hips.

headline.main: Exposing the Perils of Eating Disorders

docs.abstract: exposing the perils of eating disorders**Jane E Brody Personal Health column on dangers of eating disorders in light of documentary Dying to Be Thin on PBS's Nova television series; photos of bone density scans showing progressive osteoporosis associated with anorexia (M)
docs.snippet: It is interesting that the Nova series on PBS chose the most food-focused month of the year to air a very candid program about eating disorders, its victims, its probable causes and the newest treatments for what psychiatrists rank among the most...

docs.lead_paragraph: For most of his life, James Mulroy of Staten Island had better than 20/20 vision. Eight years ago, when he was already in his 50's, a decade later than most people, he started needing reading glasses to see close up. Then a couple of years ago, although he could still see clearly at far distances, the sphere of blurriness started expanding outward. He was becoming farsighted.

headline.main: In a Burst of Laser Heat, Farsightedness Is Zapped

docs.abstract: New procedure, called laser thermal keratoplasty, is now approved for treating low or moderate farsightedness in people at least 40 years old; procedure described; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Whatever the potential hazards of scuba diving, a new study finds, long-term brain damage is not one of them -- as long as there are no mishaps during the ascent. Contradicting earlier studies that found evidence of brain damage in regular recreational divers, German scientists writing in the current issue of Neurology report no problems for divers in normal situations, at least as far as the brain is concerned.

headline.main: Scuba Diving's Effect on the Brain

docs.abstract: Two studies published in journal Neurology finds that scuba diving does not cause permanent brain damage, as long as there are no mishaps during ascent and diver does not have certain heart condition; photo (S)
docs.snippet: Whatever the potential hazards of scuba diving, a new study finds, long-term brain damage is not one of them -- as long as there are no mishaps during the ascent.    Contradicting earlier studies that found evidence of brain damage in regular...

docs.lead_paragraph: Mr. P. died twice on an unusually quiet night in the cardiac care unit. A mystery from the beginning, he had been brought in by ambulance almost a month earlier after falling into a pane of glass. His heart stopped in the emergency room while getting his forehead stitched and no one understood why. By all accounts he had been healthy most of his 50-odd years. But that night, he was resuscitated and put on a ventilator.
docs.abstract: Dr Dandeep Jauhar article on rare Lazarus phenomenon, in which patient appears to die but after period of time spontaneously comes back to life (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the 1980's, federal health officials published a map of sorts that set off alarm bells in South Carolina. ''We had double the national rate of neural tube defects, so South Carolina was considered the hot spot in the nation,'' said Maureen Vicaria, a March of Dimes official in the state. ''If you looked at the map of the United States, there was this bull's-eye in South Carolina.''

headline.main: Campaign Touts the Benefits of Folic Acid

docs.abstract: South Carolina's extensive public education program encouraging women to take supplements of folic acid, a B vitamin , has succeeded in halving number of neural tube birth defects; these defects range from spina bifida, generally survivable but crippling disease, to usually fatal anencephaly and encephalocele, in which skull and brain do not develop properly; state's experience has helped shape broader national campaign to promote use of folic acid being coordinated by March of Dimes; since folic acid is effective only at very beginning of pregnancy, next goal is to reach not only women contemplating having baby but entire population of women of childbearing years (M)
